title: Java Data Types
text: As explained in the previous chapter, a variable in Java must be a specified data type:

Example
int myNum = 5;               // Integer (whole number)
float myFloatNum = 5.99f;    // Floating point number
char myLetter = 'D';         // Character
boolean myBool = true;       // Boolean
String myText = "Hello";     // String


Try it Yourself »
Data types are divided into two groups:

title: Primitive Data Types
text: A primitive data type specifies the type of a variable and the kind of values it can hold.
There are eight primitive data types in Java:

Data Type

Description


byte

Stores whole numbers from -128 to 127


short

Stores whole numbers from -32,768 to 32,767


int

Stores whole numbers from -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647


long

Stores whole numbers from -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 
9,223,372,036,854,775,807


float

Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for 
storing 6 to 7 decimal digits


double

Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for 
storing 15 to 16 decimal digits


boolean

Stores true or false values


char

Stores a single character/letter or ASCII values
